Authors: Andrew W. Wilson, Kentaro Hosaka, Gregory M Mueller
Title:
Evolution of ectomycorrhizae as a driver of diversification
and biogeographic patterns in the model mycorrhizal mushroom genus
Laccaria
Abstract:
 A comprehensive systematic and evolutionary ecology study
of the model ectomycorrhizal genus Laccaria was performed using
herbarium material and field collections from over 30 countries and
covering its known geographic range.  A four-gene (nrITS, 28S, RPB2,
EF1α) nucleotide sequence dataset consisting of 232 Laccaria specimens
was analyzed phylogenetically. The resulting Global Laccaria dataset was
used for molecular dating and estimating diversification rates in the
genus. Stable isotope analysis of C and N was used to evaluate the
origins of Laccarias ectomycorrhizal ecology.  116 Laccaria molecular
species were identified resulting in a near 50% increase in its known
diversity. Molecular dating indicates that the most recent common
ancestor to Laccaria existed in the middle of the Eocine, likely in
Australasia. At this time, Laccaria split into two lineages: one
represented by the taxon L. BASAL, and the other reflects a large shift
in diversification that resulted in the remainder of Laccaria. Isotopic
analysis shows that L. BASAL has a different isotopic profile than other
Laccaria species.  Isotopes and diversification results suggest that the
evolution of the ECM ecology was a key innovation in the evolution of
Laccaria. Diversification shifts associated with dispersal to the
Northern Hemisphere are also attributed to Laccarias ECM ecology since
dispersal provided new ECM hosts and ecological niches.
